questions.text: A 55-year-old woman, who is a known case of carcinoma breast, had blurred vision, nausea and vomiting. After a few weeks,​ the patient developed clumsiness of both hands and imbalance that has led to several falls. MRI revealed cerebellar atrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of the patient?
questions.solution:
Serum anti-Yo (PCA1) is assessed to evaluate for paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration.

The presence of gait and limb ataxia and subacute onset of symptoms together with MRI findings of cerebellar atrophy is suggestive of paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration mainly due to extensive degeneration of purkinje cells.

The syndrome occurs due to the antibodies that develop against the neural proteins expressed by the tumors, which cross-react with normal neuronal tissue.

The tumors commonly involved include:

  • Small cell lung cancer
  • Breast carcinoma
  • Ovarian carcinoma
  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma

The anti neuronal antibodies may be detected in the serum and/or CSF.

These antibodies causing cerebellar syndrome include:

Antibodies Tumor associated
Purkinje cell cytoplasmic antibody type 1 (PCA1), also called Anti-yo Carcinoma of the breast, ovary
Antibodies against voltage gated calcium channels (Anti-VGCC) Small cell lung cancer
Anti-Tr (or anti-Delta/Notch-like epidermal growth factor-related receptor [DNER]) Hodgkin’s lymphoma
Anti Metabotropic glutamate receptor 1 (mGluR1) Hodgkin’s lymphoma

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was admitted to the hospital with recurrent infections. His gait was uncoordinated and ocular examination revealed ocular telangiectasia in the right eye. Which of the following is the most likely mode of inheritance of the disease described in the clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of uncoordinated gait and ocular telangiectasia in the given scenario are suggestive of ataxia-telangiectasia, and the mode of inheritance of this disease is autosomal recessive.

Ataxia-telangiectasia is a syndrome complex that comprises neurologic, immunologic, endocrinologic, and cutaneous disorders. The gene involved in this condition is the mutation in the ATM gene mapped to the long arm of chromosome 11(11q22-23). There is defective DNA repair and increased sensitivity to ionizing radiation. A hypoplastic thymus is present in this condition.

The age of onset of telangiectasia is around 3 to 6 years. By 12 years of age, affected children are usually confined to wheelchairs due to progressive ataxia. 

Clinical features:

  • Progressive cerebellar ataxia
  • Oculocutaneous telangiectasias
  • Chronic sinopulmonary disease
  • High incidence of malignancy: adenocarcinomas and lymphoreticular tumors (lymphoma, leukemia, and Hodgkin's disease)
  • Humoral and cellular immunodeficiency

questions.text: You are assessing a patient with Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus. What type of gait would you expect to see?

choices.text: Excessive hip flexion and slapping of one foot

questions.solution:
Broad-based and shuffling is the most likely gait you would expect to see in a patient with Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH). 

This gait is characterized by a wide/broad-base, shuffling, short strides, and hesitation with starting and turning.

Normal pressure hydrocephalus presents with a characteristic clinical triad of ataxia in the form of broad/wide-based gait (magnetic gait), urinary incontinence, and dementia. Since intracranial pressure is normal, there will be no papilledema in patients with normal pressure hydrocephalus.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a communicating hydrocephalus (non-obstructive hydrocephalus) caused by delayed resorption of cerebrospinal fluid. Meningeal scarring is seen in some patients, due to previous history of meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or head trauma.

On imaging, dilated lateral ventricles are seen. Lumbar puncture opening pressure is in the normal to high range.

Treatment includes ventricular shunting. Gait improves more than cognition.

Option A. Unsteady, falling towards one side is suggestive of a vestibular condition such as Meniere's disease, vestibular neuritis or labyrinthitis.

Option B. Short steps, shuffling and festinant is a description of festinating gait, which is seen in Parkinson's disease.

Option C. Excessive hip flexion and slapping of one foot is a description of slapping gait, which is seen in motor neuropathy - eg common peroneal neuropathy.

questions.text: Which of the given conditions will not lead to the abnormal sign shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Trendelenburg’s sign, which is caused mainly due to the injury to gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, or superior gluteal nerve (nerve supplying the abductors), and not inferior gluteal nerve.

Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb.

Causes of positive Trendelenburg sign:

  • Paralysis of abductor muscles: Gluteus medius and gluteus minimus (injury, polio)
  • Damage to the superior gluteal nerve
  • Dislocation of the hip
  • Destruction of the head of the femur
  • Fracture neck of the femur

questions.text:
Which of the following sequences correctly represents the phases of the gait cycle during a single stride?
  1. Heel strike
  2. Push off
  3. Acceleration
  4. Mid Stance
  5. Mid Swing
  6. Deceleration
questions.solution:
The correct sequence for the phases of the gait cycle is:

Heel strike -> Mid Stance -> Push Off -> Acceleration -> Mid Swing -> Deceleration

A normal gait follows a specific pattern, consisting of multiple gait cycles. A gait cycle is defined as the interval from the heel strike of one leg to its next heel strike. The gait cycle is divided into two phases:

a) Stance phase

b) Swing phase

Stance phase: This phase of the gait cycle occurs when the foot is in contact with the ground. It begins with the heel strike and ends with the toe off, making up 60 percent of the gait cycle. The stance phase includes three key events:

- Heel strike: The moment the heel makes contact with the ground.
- Mid stance: When the entire foot is flat on the ground.
- Push off: When the body is propelled forward by pushing off the ground with the foot; the heel lifts first, followed by the toes.

Swing phase: This phase occurs when the foot is off the ground. It begins with the toe off and ends when the foot is ready to strike the ground again. The swing phase accounts for 40 percent of the gait cycle and includes the following events:

- Acceleration: Once the foot leaves the ground, the leg moves forward with the help of hip flexors.
- Mid swing: The midpoint of the leg’s forward motion.
- Deceleration: The leg slows down to prepare the foot for the next heel strike.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with recent confusion and difficulty in doing daily activities of living. She also has recent urinary incontinence and walks with a magnetic gait. She has a past history of meningitis. Which of the following is the definitive management of her condition?
questions.solution:
The classic triad of dementia(difficulties in activities of daily living and confusion), hypokinetic magnetic gait, and urinary incontinence seen in this patient suggest normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). The definitive treatment of this condition is ventriculoperitoneal shunting to reduce the intracranial pressure on the surrounding brain tissue.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a communicating hydrocephalus caused by delayed resorption of cerebrospinal fluid. Meningeal scarring is seen in some patients, due to previous history of meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or head trauma.

It presents with the characteristic triad of

  • Dementia (mostly executive function),
  • Ataxic or apractic gait, and
  • Urinary incontinence (sometimes urgency too).

It is classified as idiopathic (primary) or symptomatic (secondary) occurring due to prior brain infection, injury, radiation, or hemorrhage. 

The etiology is poorly understood but is thought to be related to the hyperdynamic flow of CSF in the aqueduct, reduced compliance of the subarachnoid space, increased CSF pulse pressure, and reduced reabsorption of CSF. 

Diagnosis: 

  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the Sylvian fissures can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy due to the propped open (so-called “boxcarring”) appearance.
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure.
  • Another confirmatory test performed is the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) tap test, which shows marked improvement of symptoms with spinal fluid removal.

Treatment: Ventriculoperitoneal shunting: It is done to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Complications of the shunting procedure include shunt obstruction, infection, intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage, malposition or breakage of the shunt, etc.

Other options:

Option B - Periodic lumbar punctures can help reduce the symptoms in pseudotumour cerebri but have no role in the management of NPH.

Option C - Levodopa-carbidopa is used in the management of Parkinsons disease which presents with tremors, rigidity, akinesia and postural instability.

Option D - Acetylcholine esterase inhibitors like rivastigmine, galantamine are used in the management of Alzheimer's disease.

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur

  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: Hyperkinetic gait is typically associated with which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
Hyperkinetic gait involves involuntary, excessive movements and is most commonly associated with Huntington’s disease. The random choreic movements give the gait a dancing quality.

Option A: Friedrich’s ataxia: It is a hereditary disorder causing progressive damage to the nervous system and the gait typically is ataxic due to loss of proprioception and coordination.

Option C: Wilson’s disease: It is a disease of copper metabolism causing a variety of movement disorders, including tremors, dystonia, and parkinsonism. These abnormal movements are often mixed and can include both hyperkinetic and hypokinetic features.

Option D: Progressive supranuclear palsy: It is a neurodegenerative disorder that typically leads to hypokinetic-rigid syndrome similar to Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man came to the Orthopedic outpatient clinic with a new complaint. He had sustained a left isolated shaft of femur fracture 6 months ago and was managed with traction in a rural health centre. He noticed a difference in his gait once he started weight-bearing exercises. Which of the following gait abnormalities is likely to be seen in him?
questions.solution:
High stepping gait is a gait abnormality seen with foot drop, which may be a complication in the shaft of femur fractures. This is due to possible injury to the sciatic nerve. The sciatic nerve runs down the back of the thigh and can be injured during trauma, leading to weakness or paralysis in the muscles it innervates, including those responsible for dorsiflexion.

A high stepping gait helps to clear the dropped foot off the ground while walking due to problems with dorsiflexion.

Another common cause for foot drop and high stepping gait can be the neck of fibula fracture causing damage to the common peroneal nerve. Temporary measures to relieve the foot drop involve physiotherapy and toe raising spring. Posterior tibialis transfer is indicated in complete foot drop.

Other options:

1. Circumduction gait is typically seen in hemiplegia or a spastic hip. The limb moves without flexion at the knee or ankle. The patient tries to clear the ground by circumducting the whole limb.

2. Trendelenburg gait is seen with the failure of the hip abduction, as seen in congenital or traumatic dislocation of the hip, non-union of fractures of the neck of femur, or gluteus medius paralysis.
In order to prevent falling, the torso tilts to the affected side, which is seen as a pelvis drop on the opposite side, and the body sways from side to side.

3. Quadriceps gait is a gait abnormality seen in polio due to quadriceps weakness and a flexion deformity. The patient limps with one hand on the knee to prevent the loss of balance from buckling of the knee.

questions.text: A child presents with neonatal hypotonia, tachypnoea, abnormal eye movements, and mental retardation. On axial imaging, the fourth ventricle is abnormally shaped with a ‘batwing appearance’ as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing the Molar tooth sign suggest the diagnosis of Joubert syndrome. The image shows an axial T2 weighted image at the level of superior cerebellar peduncles demonstrating the molar tooth sign.

Joubert syndrome:

These are a group of recessive congenital ataxia disorders in which typically there is

  • Neonatal hypotonia
  • Tachypnoea
  • Abnormal eye movements
  • Mental retardation associated with a particular pattern of cerebellar dysgenesis with a molar tooth-type malformation and vermis hypoplasia

MRI features :

  • The cardinal feature is the presence of a molar tooth sign which is created by a combination of
    • Midbrain hypoplasia with an
    • Abnormally deep interpeduncular fossa and
    • A failure of the superior cerebellar peduncles to decussate across the midline.
  • On axial imaging, the fourth ventricle is abnormally shaped with a batwing appearance
  • Cerebellar hypoplasia
  • Midline vermian cleft
  • Dysplastic small vermis
  • The midbrain is small

Related Pearl: Investigation of choice in Neurology

Generally, MRI is considered the best imaging for the spinal cord and nerves.

Conditions in which MRI is used include:

  • Optic neuritis
  • Vestibular schwannoma
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Spinal cord tumor
  • Neurofibroma
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Hippocampal volumetry.

CT scan is preferred when the timing is critical. So, the investigation of choice for stroke is an NCCT. This helps to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

The investigation of choice for ischemic stroke is a diffusion-weighted MRI.

questions.text: Which of the following is primarily responsible for the development of a scissoring gait in children with cerebral palsy?

choices.text: Weakness of the hip abductor muscles
Spasticity of the hip adductor muscles

questions.solution:
Scissoring gait in children with cerebral palsy is primarily caused by the spasticity of the hip adductor muscles- adductor longus, adductor brevis, and adductor magnus.

The excessive tone in these muscles pulls the legs inward, causing them to cross in a scissoring fashion and leading to the characteristic gait abnormality.

Option A: Spasticity of the quadriceps muscles: Spasticity in these muscles can lead to knee hyperextension or a stiff-legged gait.

Option B: Spasticity of the gastrocnemius muscles: This typically leads to an equinus deformity or toe-walking.

Option C: Weakness of the hip abductor muscles: This leads to the Trendelenburg gait.

questions.text: A man presented with slurred speech and festinating shuffling gait. He tells that a course of levodopa was advised by his previous doctor but didn't show any effect. Which of the following mineral toxicity/ deficiency causes such features?
questions.solution:
Manganese toxicity can cause secondary parkinsonism with features similar to atypical parkinsonism.

Secondary parkinsonism is characterized by Parkinson-like disease caused by agents/factors that cause basal ganglia dysfunction. These factors include drugs (tetrabenazine, metoclopramide, neuroleptics, flunarizine), stroke, tumor, infection, or toxins. Clinical features will be based on the region of the basal ganglia that has been damaged.

Toxins such as carbon monoxide or manganese produce damage to the globus pallidus, and hence present with features resembling atypical parkinsonism such as:

  • Early speech and gait impairment
  • Repeated early falls
  • Absence of rest tremor
  • No motor asymmetry
  • Poor or no response to levodopa
  • Aggressive clinical course
  • Symptoms of severe early autonomic involvement

Manganese deficiency on the other hand can result in poor growth, bone demineralization, ataxia, convulsions, and abnormalities in carbohydrate and lipid metabolism.

Other options

Option A: Selenium deficiency causes Keshan disease (cardiomyopathy in endemic regions of China); Excess selenium intake leads to selenosis (with hair loss, brittle nails, garlic breath odor, myopathy, and neurologic symptoms).

Option B: Zinc toxicity leads to nausea, vomiting, headache, fever, and hypersalivation. Zinc deficiency causes dwarfism, hypogonadism, hypopigmented hair, hypogeusia, and impaired immunity.

Option D: Hypomagnesemia is characterized by neurologic symptoms like tremors, muscle weakness, ataxia, delirium, and psychosis. Hypermagnesemia causes lethargy, weakness, hypotonia, weak tendon reflexes, and coma.

questions.text: All of the following can present with circumduction gait except
questions.solution:
Hip adductors spasticity can not present with circumduction gait. It typically causes the leg to pull inward, leading to a scissor gait rather than circumduction.

Option A: Hip flexor weakness: Causes difficulty in advancing the leg during the swing phase, leading to circumduction to clear the foot.

Option B: Leg length discrepancy: The longer leg may require circumduction to prevent the foot from dragging on the ground.

Option C: Ankle dorsiflexion weakness: Leads to foot drop, which often results in circumduction to avoid the foot dragging.

questions.text: Which of the following can be associated with focal ataxia?
questions.solution:

Focal ataxia is often caused by cerebrovascular disease, most commonly due to ischemic stroke or cerebellar hemorrhage. These lesions generally result in cerebellar symptoms on the same side as the affected area.

All the mentioned causes result in symmetrical ataxia

questions.text: A patient walks with a stomping gait. When asked to close his eyes and walk, he is unable to do so. Which of the following tracts is probably affected?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms and test indicates the involvement of the posterior column.

As our feet touch the ground, we receive proprioceptive information to tell us their location. The stomping gait occurs when there is a loss of this proprioceptive input. In an effort to know when the feet land and their location, the patient will slam the foot hard onto the ground in order to sense it. A key to this gait involves its exacerbation when patients cannot see their feet (i.e. in the dark). The patients may lift their legs very high to hit the ground hard.

It is seen in conditions where the posterior column or proprioception is affected like vitamin B12 deficiency and diabetic neuropathy.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect action about the structure marked with '?' in the following clinical and cadaveric images.

choices.text: It enhances the economy of bipedal locomotion
It is active during the swing phase of gait
It is active during the stance phase of gait
It helps to effect eversion of the foot

questions.solution:
The '?' marked structure in the clinical and cadaveric image is peroneus tertius. It is not active during the stance phase of gait.

Peroneus tertius/ Fibularis tertius:

It is a part of the anterior compartment of the leg.

Attachments: It often appears to be part of the extensor digitorum longus and might be described as its ‘fifth tendon’. Its fibers arise from the distal third or more of the medial surface of the fibula, the adjoining anterior surface of the interosseous membrane, and the anterior intermuscular septum. It is inserted onto the medial part of the dorsal surface of the base of the fifth metatarsal; a thin expansion usually extends forwards along the medial border of the shaft of the bone.

Relations: It lies lateral to the extensor digitorum longus.

Innervation: It is innervated by the deep fibular nerve, L5, S1.

Actions: During the swing phase of gait, it acts with extensor digitorum longus and tibialis anterior to produce dorsiflexion of the foot, and with fibularis longus and fibularis brevis to effect eversion of the foot. This helps in improving efficiency and enhances the economy of bipedal locomotion. It is not active during the stance phase.

Testing: It cannot be tested in isolation, but its tendon can sometimes be seen and felt when the foot is dorsiflexed against resistance (as shown in the above image).

The animations below show a superior and inferior view of the peroneus muscles. The muscle marked with blue is the peroneus longus, red is the peroneus brevis, and green is the peroneus tertius.

questions.text:
Match the following gaits with the respective disorders in which they are typically seen.
  1. Circumduction gait
  2. Trendelenburg gait
  3. Quadriceps gait
  4. High-stepping gait
  1. Sciatic Nerve Injury
  2. Hemiplegia
  3. Gluteus medius paralysis
  4. Polio
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

  1. Circumduction gait - Hemiplegia
  2. Trendelenburg gait - Gluteus medius paralysis
  3. Quadriceps gait - Polio
  4. High-stepping gait - Sciatic Nerve Injury 

High-stepping gait is a gait abnormality seen with foot drop due to injury to the sciatic nerve. A high stepping gait helps to clear the dropped foot off the ground while walking due to problems with dorsiflexion. Temporary measures to relieve the foot drop involve physiotherapy and toe raising spring. Posterior tibialis transfer is indicated in complete foot drop.

Circumduction gait is typically seen in hemiplegia or a spastic hip. The limb moves without flexion at the knee or ankle. The patient tries to clear the ground by circumducting the whole limb.

Trendelenburg gait is seen with the failure of the hip abduction, as seen in congenital or traumatic dislocation of the hip, non-union of fractures of the neck of the femur, or gluteus medius paralysis. In order to prevent falling, the torso tilts to the affected side, which is seen as a pelvis drop on the opposite side, and the body sways from side to side.

Quadriceps gait is a gait abnormality seen in polio due to quadriceps weakness and flexion deformity. The patient limps with one hand on the knee to prevent the loss of balance from buckling of the knee.

questions.text: A 5-year-old female child with polyneuropathy, sensorineural deafness, and cerebellar ataxia has the following finding on fundus examination. Lab reveals increased blood levels of phytanic acid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows fundoscopy findings of retinitis pigmentosa. This along with the given clinical scenario is suggestive of Refsum’s disease. 

Refsum's disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder that results from the defect in alpha oxidation of fatty acids such as phytanic acid in the peroxisome leading to elevated levels of phytanic acid in the blood. 

In this condition, the enzyme phytanoyl CoA hydroxylase is defective and causes the accumulation of phytanic acid. Clinically, patients present with dysmorphic facies and severe neurological symptoms such as polyneuropathy, retinitis pigmentosa, nerve deafness, ichthyosis, and cerebellar ataxia. Regression of symptoms is observed with restricted dietary intake of phytanic acid. Therefore, management includes avoiding sources of phytanic acid such as dairy products, meat, nuts, and green leafy vegetables.

Note: The Zellweger spectrum is a continuum of diseases of persoxisome defects with Zellweger syndrome (most severe) at one end, neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy in the middle (intermediate severity) and infantile Refsum's disease (least severe) at the other end.

Option B- Usher syndrome is characterized by sensorineural deafness and retinitis pigmentosa (but symptoms are not affected by restricting phytanic acid)

Option C- Zellweger Syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX/Peroxin family of genes involved in peroxisome biogenesis /peroxisomal enzymes. There is severe neurologic symptoms and patients usually die in the 1st year of life.

Option D- Adrenoleukodystrophy is a disorder of β-oxidation of fatty acids. There is a very large chain fatty acids buildup in the adrenal glands, the white matter of the brain, and testes.

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text:
A patient complains of difficulty in maintaining balance while walking at night for the past 2 months. On examination, he has spastic weakness in both lower limbs, a positive Babinski sign, and an absent ankle jerk. Laboratory results are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

Hemoglobin: 13 g/dL

MCV: within normal limits
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sensory ataxia (patient is unable to maintain balance without visual input), UMN signs (spasticity and positive Babinski sign), and absence of ankle jerk due to peripheral neuropathy point to a diagnosis of subacute combined degeneration of cord (SACD). Note that neurological symptoms of vitamin B12 deficiency can occur without anemia and macrocytosis.

SACD is a degeneration of the dorsal and lateral columns of the spinal cord, which occurs as a result of vitamin B12 deficiency. Patients present with sensory ataxia (involvement of the dorsal column) and UMN type of motor symptoms such as spasticity and positive Babinski sign (involvement of corticospinal tract). Because of coexisting peripheral neuropathy, deep tendon reflexes can be absent. Some patients also develop cortical defects such as dementia.

The treatment of vitamin B12 deficiency when the patient has neurological symptoms is with cyanocobalamine 1000 mcg given intramuscularly, first daily for 1 week → then weekly for 1 month → then monthly for the rest of the patient's life.

Other options:

Option A: Although UMN type of motor symptoms are seen in ischemic stroke as well, they are unilateral. Furthermore, stroke is an acute onset clinical syndrome, while this patient has had these complaints for the past 2 months.

Option B: Patients with syringomyelia present with weakness in arms more than legs and loss of pain and temperature sensation over the shoulders, upper back, and nape of the neck (cape-like distribution). Fine touch, vibration, and joint position sense remain preserved.

Option C: Tabes dorsalis primarily affects the dorsal columns, leading to sensory ataxia and absent reflexes, it does not cause spasticity or a positive Babinski sign, as it spares the corticospinal tracts.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with dizziness, unsteadiness and difficulty walking since the past few hours. On examination, the child has ataxia, wide-based gait, decreased responsiveness and peri oral rash. His father reports that he has been behaving strangely and was caught bunking school. What is the most likely cause of the child's symptoms?
questions.solution:
This is a scenario of toluene inhalation intoxication presenting acutely with neurologic symptoms and signs of symmetric ataxia, wide based gait and peri oral rash (glue sniffer's rash).

Inhalants are compounds like butane, propane, freons and toluene. These are present in household items like glue, paint thinners, whiteners and hairsprays. These compounds are easily available, thus they're easy to abuse.

Inhalant intoxication presents with symptoms like euphoria, agitation, anxiety and decreased responsiveness. The effects last for a few hours after the inhalation. Inhalant use can also acutely cause symmetric ataxia, and long term use is also associated with local perioral dermatitis known as "glue sniffer's rash".

Inhalant intoxication can be harmful as repeated inhalation can lead to hypoxia, coma and long term use has been associated with delirium and dementia.

Use of intoxicants or drugs must be elicited in patient visits to determine early symptoms of mental disorders and functional impairment in pediatric populations. This can be done through a HEADSSS assessment (Home, Education, Activities, Drugs, Sexuality, Suicide/Depression, Safety).

Other toxic causes of ataxia include alcohol, lithium, phenytoin, barbiturates, mercury, gasoline and glue inhalation.

Other options : 

Option A : Friedrich's ataxia would present as chronic ataxia, and not acutely as in this patient. Friedreich's ataxia is the most common form of inherited ataxia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder generally occurring in individuals less than 25 years of age. It is caused by the expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in the first intron of a gene on chromosome 9q13 that encodes frataxin. Patients present with clinical features of dysarthria, progressive staggering gait, frequent falls, nystagmus, and titubation (nodding head and body movements).

Option C : Postinfectious cerebellitis is a reversible cerebellar ataxia and a rare acute or subacute complication of varicella zoster infection.

Option D : Ataxia telangiectasia is a rare inherited cause of ataxia. Patients present in the first decade of life with progressive telangiectatic lesions associated with deficits in cerebellar function and nystagmus.
